awd_titl_txt: SHF: Medium: Collaborative Research: Semantically-Enhanced Software Traceability for Supporting Human-Centric Tasks
awd_abstract_narration:
Achieving accurate, complete, trustworthy and usable traceability across software-intensive systems can be extremely beneficial as the underlying network of traceability links can be used to answer diverse questions about the software system and its development process.  However, in practice, many software projects suffer from inadequate or inaccurate traceability due to the cost and difficulty of manually creating and maintaining trace links.    This research will develop a holistic, interactive tracing environment, which incorporates diverse algorithmic solutions for dynamically generating trace links, visualizing the results, and guiding the user through the interactive process of using the results to support diverse Software Engineering tasks. Automating the creation and maintenance of accurate traceability links offers significant potential for industrial impact. For example, traceability is required by certifying bodies in safety-critical domains and can help in the construction and delivery of high quality, competitive, timely products.  The cross-disciplinary nature of the team will introduce new opportunities for software engineers, data scientists, and human-computer interaction experts to collaborate in addressing open Software Engineering challenges and will provide research opportunities for diverse and underrepresented students.

The research will explore challenging problems at the intersection of software engineering, semantic text mining, and visualization.  It will directly address one of the prominent causes of trace-link inaccuracy caused by the inability of current algorithms to reason over deep semantics of underlying software artifacts such as requirements, design, and code.  First, the researchers will investigate semantically enhanced traceability algorithms that generate trace links, even in the absence of shared textual representations. Second, the work will develop a holistic tracing solution that dynamically configures a trace engine to leverage diverse tracing techniques such as semantic traceability, trace link evolution, and other existing techniques. Finally, given a diverse set of trace links with different degrees of accuracy, the research team will design, develop, and publicly release a novel, interactive, visual interface that enables users to understand the provenance and trustworthiness of each link while providing a clear rationale for trace query results.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Computer and Information Science and Engineering
org_div_long_name: Division of Computing and Communication Foundations

pgm_ref.pgm_ref_txt: REU SUPP-Res Exp for Ugrd Supp

por.por_cntn:
Ensuring that software systems function correctly and safely is critical, especially in domains such as healthcare, finance, and aerospace failures can have significant consequences, including financial loss, safety risks, and regulatory violations. One essential aspect of software engineering is traceability—the ability to link different software artifacts (such as requirements, design documents, code, and tests) to one another. Effective traceability helps developers verify compliance, track changes, and understand the impact of modifications, but maintaining these links has historically been difficult and time-consuming. This project aimed to transform traceability by developing an intelligent, user-centered environment that automates and improves the accuracy of trace link generation. By integrating cutting-edge artificial intelligence (AI) techniques—including deep learning, natural language processing (NLP), and semantic reasoning—we worked to make traceability more reliable, transparent, and practical for real-world software development. Our approach emphasized both automation and human interaction, ensuring that users could refine and validate trace results with confidence.

A key technical contribution of this research was the advancement of AI-driven traceability methods, significantly improving how software trace links are generated and maintained. In the early stages of the project, we explored deep learning models, such as BERT, to increase accuracy in linking software artifacts, achieving major gains in precision and recall. We also developed interactive visualization tools to help users understand AI-generated trace links and provide explanations for why certain artifacts were connected. As our research progressed, we expanded beyond traditional tracing techniques to include semantic enhancements, using large language models (LLMs) to develop ontologies and taxonomies—structured representations of knowledge that help software engineers navigate and interpret complex projects. Innovations such as Chain-of-Layer, Dict-BERT, and GenTaxo allowed us to automatically build domain-specific taxonomies, filling gaps in existing knowledge and improving trace link accuracy. In addition, we introduced hierarchical documentation generation, enabling AI to dynamically extract and structure software documentation from source code. This HGEN pipeline allowed for the automatic creation of documentation layers—such as system overviews, requirements, and user stories—while linking them through a traceability-aware framework. These advances made it significantly easier for engineers to understand and maintain large, complex software systems.

Beyond its intellectual contributions, this project has had a broad impact on both academia and industry. Our findings have been published in top-tier venues such as ICSE, ACL, KDD, and ICSME, influencing research in software engineering, AI, and human-computer interaction. More importantly, we translated our research into a tangible industry solution through the development of the SAFA platform, which integrates AI-driven traceability, semantic enrichment, and automated documentation generation into an industry-ready tool. SAFA enables organizations to apply cutting-edge AI techniques to improve traceability, visualize complex project relationships, and generate structured documentation hierarchies—all within a scalable, automated environment. Deployed in multiple pilot programs, SAFA has demonstrated its ability to enhance software engineering practices in real-world settings. By reducing the effort required to maintain trace links and improving the quality of software documentation, this work supports safer, more reliable, and more efficient software development. Ultimately, this project has contributed to the advancement of AI-driven, semantically enriched, and interactive traceability solutions, helping to integrate them into software engineering practice.


Last Modified: 02/07/2025
Modified by: Jane L Huang

Images (1 of )
  • Slice of documentation and links generated for Autoware open source project using HGEN.
    Katherine Dearstyne
    Copyright owner is an institution with an existing agreement allowing use by NSF
    Jane L Huang
    A slice of automatically generated documentation
  • GenTaxo Architecture: When a concept is masked, the model predicts its name using taxonomy. Sequence encoders process relations, while graph encoders aggregate subgraph data. Fused hidden states validate the position (Task 1) and feed GRU decoders to generate the name (Task 2).
    Meng Jiang
    Copyrighted
    Jane L Huang
    Architecture of GenTaxo
  • Chain-of-Layer Architecture: Given an entity list and root, Chain-of-Layer organizes entities hierarchically, adding them top-down. It selects entities, extends the taxonomy, and refines relations with a ranking filter to reduce errors, repeating until all entities are integrated.
    Meng Jiang
    Copyrighted
    Jane L Huang
    Chain-of-layers architecture
  • Project overview screen containing Traceability Information Model (TIM) and graph controls and a generated project summary.
    Katherine Dearstyne
    Copyrighted
    Jane L Huang
    Traceability Information Model
  • Architecture of CodeTaxo: CodeTaxo reformulates the task of integrating a query entity into an existing taxonomy as a code completion task using code-based prompts for large language models.
    Meng Jiang
    Copyrighted
    Jane L Huang
    CODE Taxo architecture
